items.content_html: Me, complaining that our toaster sometimes is a jerk: It‚Äôs 2018, it‚Äôs nearly 2019! It‚Äôs not hard to build electronics that compensate for a warm heating element and decrease the cook time accordingly Lindsay: Oh my god, it‚Äôs a toaster let‚Äôs get mad about Me: I mean, I listened to a podcast where toasters were reviewed‚Ä¶ Lindsay: üò∂ Are you ok? Do you need friends? Me: Well, I‚Ä¶ Lindsay: I mean, I know you‚Äôre a nerd but sometimes you really amaze me with how much of a nerd you really are.
I‚Äôve been fighting with In-Air WiFi all day, and as frustrating as it is it‚Äôs also still incredible.

items.title: Dr. Zeynep Tufekci on the Fundamentally Broken Incentive Structure in Social Media Business Models
items.content_html:
Russian Meddling Is a Symptom, Not the Disease

Facebook, Twitter and YouTube have business models that thrive on the outrageous, the incendiary and the eye-catching, because such content generates ‚Äúengagement‚Äù and captures our attention, which the platforms then sell to advertisers, paired with extensive data on users that allow advertisers (and propagandists) to ‚Äúmicrotarget‚Äù us at an individual level.

The way social media incentivized divisive, eye-catching (and often factually incomplete if not entirely wrong) posts is a huge problem we don‚Äôt talk about or have any idea how to fix. And don‚Äôt look to Google and Facebook to fix this problem: to them, this problem is engagement, and makes their platforms more valuable.
I have two tickets available for Stuff You Missed in History Class Live in Seattle on the 13th. If you or someone you know wants ‚Äòem, let me know.

via Gfycat

I animated FanGraphs‚Äô projected playoff odds for the MLB each day of the season to commemorate the Mariners‚Äô extraordinary failure.

I‚Äôm an Orioles and Mariners fan. This hurts. Actually, the next few seasons are probably going to hurt. ‚öæÔ∏è

items.title: 20 Songs
items.content_html:
@bradbarrish linked a playlist of 20 songs that ‚Äútruly represent [his] muscial point-of-view‚Äù. I loved the idea. It‚Äôs a vague prompt, and I‚Äôm interpreting it as 20 songs that shaped my musical taste. I‚Äôve ordered these in roughly chronological order of when I was introduced to the songs, not when they were released.

I‚Äôm also using this as an excuse to write up my memories of these songs, how I came to them, and what they meant to me. I wanted to pull this thread all the way through and add songs that are currently at the end of the threads these songs start, but the 20 song limitation wasn‚Äôt enough. That would be a fun follow-on.

tl;dr:

  • Apple Music Playlist
  • Spotify Playlist

  1. Jim Croce - Operator

    My Dad‚Äôs musical taste was varied, but I think he only knew four or five artists‚Äô names: Harry Belafonte, Randy Travis, Engelbert Humperdink, Neal Diamond, and Jim Croche. They all grated on me, except for Jim. Bad, Bad Leroy Brown, Time In a Bottle, I Got A Name. My favorite was the heartbreaking conversation Jim had with the operator when thinking of calling his ex. That‚Äôs still a resonant theme in music, some things don‚Äôt change. Simple guitar, a swelling refrain, and long car rides with my old man.

  2. Beach Boys - Sloop John B.

    Mom gave me a cassette of the Beach Boys‚Äô greatest hits when I was 3 or 4. I listened to it so much, I stretched the tape. I begged for a replacement, and stretched that one. Had to wait for a birthday to get another replacement. Sloop John B. and Wouldn‚Äôt It Be Nice were my favorites, but if I have to pick one, it‚Äôs an easy decision.

  3. Beatles - Eleanor Rigby

    Concept Beatles are the best Beatles, and the grimy English city life that Eleanor Rigby evoked just really did it for me. The feeling of indvidualsliving in shared lonlieness is so well captured, and the string backing is perfect.

  4. Billy Joel - Downeaster ‚ÄúAlexa‚Äù

    Storm Front was one of the first albums I asked my parents to buy me, after hearing the single We Didn‚Äôt Start the Fire. Downeaster Alexa was hurt.

  5. Heart - Barracuda

    I don‚Äôt have a specific memory of Barracuda, but I knew all the words as a kid, and it‚Äôs directly applicable to my love of Garbage, Amanda Palmer, Tori Amos, Pretty Girls Make Graves, etc. etc.

  6. Amy Irving and Charles Fleischer - Why Don‚Äôt You Do Right?

    Like so many boys of my generation, I found Jessica Rabbit‚Ä¶eye opening. She turned me on to a lot of things, and one of them was smoky, sultry jazz singers.

  7. Pink Floyd - Is Anybody Out There

    I heard this song entirely out of context sitting on the floor of the living room of my childhood home, idly listening to my dad‚Äôs massive box of mixtapes and tapes of songs he‚Äôd recorded from the radio (remember how satisfying it was to get a perfect recording where you started the tape at just the right moment and the DJ didn‚Äôt interrupt with some asinine commentary), and Syd Barrett‚Äôs asking for acknowledgement resonated so strongly in me. I had no idea who it was - Dad didn‚Äôt know - but six or eight years later I heard The Wall, and everything made sense.

  8. Ramones - I Wanna Be Sedated

    Energetic beats paird with lyrics of not wanting to feel this constant energy hit close to home. That‚Äôs being a teenager.

  9. David Bowie - Rock ‚Äòn‚Äô Roll Suicide

    ‚ÄùOh! No, love, you‚Äôre not alone!‚Äù Chills. Every time.

  10. The Doors - The End

    There aren‚Äôt words for The End, so I won‚Äôt force them.

  11. Del the Funky Homosapien - If You Must

    Turned on by the Tony Hawk Pro Skater soundtrack, I couldn‚Äôt get enough of Del. When I heard Deltron 3030, it floored me. Hip Hop could be crerebral and funny and fun. It seems obvious now, but this was eye opening. (Pretty sure I remember it being ‚ÄúDel the Funkee Homosapien‚Äù and ‚ÄúIf Ya Must‚Äù on the game, though)

  12. Tori Amos - Datura

    A friend at summer camp let me borrow Under the Pink overnight, and I listened to it in my bunk. I liked it, but she liked it more than I did, and that fact limited how close our friendship could be. To Venus and Back, on the other hand, grabbed me immediately and hasn‚Äôt let go. It‚Äôs been nearly 20 years.

  13. The Cure - Just Like Heaven
  14. Depeche Mode - Enjoy the Silence
  15. Nine Inch Nails - Sanctified

  16. New Order - Age of Consent

    These four, together, capture my teenage industrial/new-wave romanticism. Age of Consent captured the feeling of seeing the fist light after partying all night in some black basement while listening to the other three. Which was pretty much how I spent my late teens and early 20s.

  17. Bjork - Human Behavior

    Oh man, Human Behavior opened my eyes. Before this, my only exposure to Bjork was It‚Äôs Oh So Quiet, which is great but made me think she was a ‚ÄúHappy music‚Äù person. Obviously, I wasn‚Äôt paying attention.

  18. Pixies - Wave of Mutilation

    I was tunred onto Pixies late, Doolittle came out in ‚Äò89, and I didn‚Äôt listen to it until I was in high school, probably a decade later. Didn‚Äôt matter. Doolittle is timeless.

  19. Tool - Parabol/Parabola

    This is a bit of a cheat, but the crescendo between the two tracks makes it. This specific transition led me into Godspeed! You Black Emperor and Mogwai. Between classes in college, I walked into one of Baltimore‚Äôs great local record shops (Record and Tape Traders, which was apparently and dissapointingly bought by FYE) and asked the guy behind the counter if he could think of anything else that made me feel the way that transition did; like a wave crashing on me, like tension being released. He nailed it. Also, this isn‚Äôt on the playlists because Tool is regressivly keeping their music off streaming services. Hope they come around.

  20. At The Drive-In - One-Armed Scissor

    In 1999, At the Drive-In was supposed to be the future of punk. Relationship of Command was excellent, but the band dissolved, and Cedric and Omar moved on to the also-phenomenal The Mars Volta.
Wallace Falls with a visiting friend and a 30# unstable pack #getoutside #dadface
I love Siri Shortcuts and I love iCloud Photos, but putting the two together is a dance of crashes to the desktop, failures without error, and disappointment.
It makes me happy that Find My Friends is ‚ÄúFind Friends‚Äù on the homescreen. Maybe one day I will, iPhone. Maybe one day I will‚Ä¶
A smoky day outside with friends is still a damn fine day. A recent #tbt to Tuesday on Mt. St. Helens with @jfuruno1, @jjfuruno, and @lindsay_alvani
Batman watering can, a hose, a four-year-old‚Äôs ingenuity, and sunshine #summer
I‚Äôve crawled deep down a Fortnite rabbithole. The past 10 days have been dark. At least I still remember my kids‚Äô names.
Aubrey the Uruk-hai #lookslikemeatsbackonthemenuboys
Summer
Made a friend while running errands this morning.
Summer
Aubrey (2) found her nipples. She asked me what they‚Äôre called and I told her. ‚ÄúMy sprinkles?‚Äù She said. So they‚Äôre sprinkles, now, and that‚Äôs my favorite thing.
This profile on Ichiro by Wright Thompson is beautiful and sad, and makes me so happy he‚Äôs a Mariner again.

I had surgery to fix a lazy eye last week. Definitely felt sluggish on 18.1 today. I was realistically targeting 200, but secretly thought if everything clicked I could hit 256. I got 197. I‚Äôd like to say I left my ego at the door, but it still took a hit.

Had an epiphany about Washingtonians this morning. They don‚Äôt feel temperature, but what they interpret as temperature is the presence or absence of sunlight. So 29¬∞F and sunny is tee-shirt weather and 50¬∞F and drizzling requires a puffy.

I just beat Kingdom: New Lands, and it‚Äôs the most fun I‚Äôve had playing an iOS game in ages. It‚Äôs so well suited to touch, it‚Äôs impressive it was on PC first.

itunes.apple.com/us/app/ki‚Ä¶
According to Iain, I guess I have 203 toes?
Trouble‚Äôs coming

items.title: Reducing my Fever
items.content_html:
I‚Äôve been using Fever for nearly a decade; the site was launched in 2008, and I was an early adopter. I‚Äôve waxed and waned my RSS reading, sometimes going through periods where Digg or Reddit or Twitter gave me more of my news, but over the past few years I‚Äôve been back in Fever a lot.

I didn‚Äôt know, but Fever‚Äôs creator and author, Shaun Inman, killed Fever and Mint over a year ago in December 2016! It‚Äôs a testament to how well written this little PHP app is, and to self-hosting software, that my instances of Fever have been so reliable for so long. I‚Äôve done almost no maintenance, occasionally clearing disk space on the server, but that‚Äôs it. It‚Äôs great. I only found out they were deprecated when I visited the site looking for information on using regex to filter specific posts from a couple of my feeds.

I‚Äôm looking for alternatives. I‚Äôm demoing Feedbin right now, and I like it so far. I do miss Fever‚Äôs clever aggregation feature1, but I might be able to get something close by liberally applying auto-read actions, which actually very easily solved my needs I was using regex filters for in Fever. Good job, Feedbin!

  1. Fever had this cool concept where some feeds could be marked as ‚ÄúSparks‚Äù. They wouldn‚Äôt show up in your unread list, but they would add to a ‚ÄúHot‚Äù section. Feed items that used similar language or linked to the same URLs would be aggregated under ‚ÄúHot‚Äù, with more popular terms and links getting a higher temperature, and thus being ‚Äúhotter‚Äù. So clever, and super useful for especially for squeezing some benefit from the really high-volume feeds that I otherwise won‚Äôt read.¬†↩
I‚Äôve spent a lot of today wondering what Dr. King would think of us, today. I suspect this look says it all. We‚Äôd do well to re-learn his lessons.
